title: A microcarrier-based protocol for scalable generation and purification of human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived neurons and astrocytes
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Neural induction of hiPSCs
Timing: ∼2 weeks
This step describes the neural induction of hiPSCs to allow for the robust generation of human neural progenitor cells (hNPCs). Neural induction is achieved through the inhibition of BMP and TGF-β signaling and the formation of embryoid bodies (EBs) (Chambers et al., 2009[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]; Kim et al., 2011[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14]). After isolation of EB-derived neuroepithelial-like rosettes, hNPCs can be replated and maintained as proliferative, multipotent cells. Prior to neural induction working concentration of relevant reagents should be made as described in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] and the necessary media should be made.
Note: HiPSCs should be grown for a minimum of two passages post-thaw prior to initiating differentiation. HiPSCs should be healthy, displaying their characteristic morphology.
Differentiation should be initiated when hiPSCs are 70–80% confluent (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A, left panels).
On day 0, aspirate the medium from the well.
Gently wash each well with 1 mL PBS. Then, add 1 mL of Accutase per well of a 6-well plate.
Incubate the plate with Accutase at 37°C for 5 min.
Wash the surface with 1 mL of DMEM to further dissociate the cells from the plate (blast cells with P1000 where necessary).
Transfer the cell suspension to a 15 mL conical tube. Take 10 μL of the cell suspension and count cells using a hemocytometer.
Centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.
Resuspend the cell pellet in E8 supplemented with 5 μM ROCKi so that the final cell concentration is 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Add 4 mL of cell suspension per well of 6-well cell-repellent plate. A total of 4 × 106 cells will be added to each well.

Note: For neural induction in suspension culture, the cells should be cultured in a 6-well cell repellent plate. To allow for appropriate cell aggregation, we do not recommend other cell culture formats be used.
Place the plate on an orbital shaker set at 95 rpm inside a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator. Aggregates in the form of embryoid bodies (EBs) should be observed 24 h post-plating (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A, right panels). Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
On day 1, carefully aspirate 3 mL of the medium from each well using a P1000 and replace with 3 mL of fresh E8 medium.
On day 2, carefully aspirate 2 mL of the medium from each well using a P1000 and replace with 2 mL of fresh E8 medium.
On day 3, carefully aspirate 3 mL of the E8 medium from each well and replace with 3 mL of NIM.
Critical: Formation of EBs in E8 medium prior to neural induction allows for more consistent aggregate size and neural induction.
On days 4–8, carefully aspirate 2 mL of the medium from each well and replace with 2 mL of NIM.
On day 9, use a 5 mL serological pipette to gently transfer aggregates to a 15 mL conical and let the aggregates settle. Transfer aggregates to a Cultrex® Basement Membrane Extract (BME) coated 6-well plate, splitting aggregates at a 1:2 ratio.
Add NIM supplemented with 5uM of ROCKi so that the total volume in each well is 3 mL. Gently move the plate in several quick, short, back-and-forth, and side-to-side motions to disperse the EBs evenly across the cell culture surface.

On day 10, EBs should have settled and adhered to the Cultrex® BME-coated plate (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B, left panels). Change the medium with NIM on days 10–15. By day 12, the EBs should spread out on the Cultrex® BME-coated plates and neural rosette-like structures should be visible (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B, right panels). Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Coating of plates with poly-L-ornithine (PLO) and laminin (Ln)
Timing: ∼8 h
This step describes the coating of plates with poly-L-ornithine (PLO) and laminin (Ln) that will be used for hNPC culture. Prior to this step, the stock solutions of PLO and Ln should be made as described in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].
To prepare PLO working solution, add 48 mL of PBS and 2 mL of PLO stock solution to a 50 mL conical.
Add 2 mL of the PLO working solution to each well of a 6-well plate.
Incubate at 37°C for 4 h.
Aspirate the PLO and wash each well twice with 2 mL PBS.
Thaw aliquots of Ln stock solution on ice.
To prepare Ln working solution, add 49.6 mL of PBS and 400 μL of Ln stock solution to a 50 mL conical.
Add 2 mL of the Ln working solution to each well of a 6-well plate.
Incubate at 37°C for 4 h.
Immediately prior to use, wash each well twice with 2 mL PBS.
Note: PLO/Ln coated plates can be stored at -20°C for 2 weeks with the Ln working solution remaining on the plate.
Neural Rosette selection
Timing: 2 days

This step describes the selective isolation of neural rosette clusters from adherent EBs. The isolated rosettes can be expanded as hNPCs in the presence of FGF and EGF (Koch et al., 2009[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]). Before starting this step, the Neural Induction Medium (NIM) should be prepared. Rosette selection is adapted from the manufacturer’s protocol for STEMdiff™ Neural Rosette Selection Reagent.
On day 16 of neural induction, aspirate NIM from the well and wash with 1 mL of DMEM/F-12.
Aspirate DMEM/F-12 and add 1 mL of STEMdiff™ Neural Rosette Selection Reagent.
Incubate at 37°C for 1.5 h.
Carefully aspirate the STEMdiff™ Neural Rosette Selection Reagent using a 1 mL pipette.
Using a P1000, firmly wash the surface with 1 mL of DMEM/F-12 to dissociate the rosettes from the plate.
Note: The DMEM/F-12 should be aimed directly at the rosettes in order to dissociate the neural rosettes from the culture surface.
Add the neural rosette suspension to a 15 mL conical tube using a 5mL serological pipette.
Repeat steps 32 and 33 until most of the rosettes have been isolated from the well. Do not over-select for rosettes. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Centrifuge rosette suspension at 300 × g for 5 min at RT.
Gently resuspend by pipetting cells in 3 mL NIM supplemented with 5 μM ROCKi 1–2 times.
Split cells at a 1:1 ratio. Add 3 mL of cell suspension to 1 well of a PLO/Ln coated 6-well plate. From herein, the cells are called hNPCs and this is considered passage 0.
Place the plate in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator. Gently move the plate in several quick, short, back-and-forth, and side-to-side motions to spread cells evenly across the wells.
The next day, change the medium with 3mL NIM.

Change the medium with fresh NIM every day until cells reach 70–80% confluence. Flat adherent cells should appear with a morphology as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C. Culture cells in NEM from passage 1.
HNPC expansion
Timing: 3–4 weeks
This step describes the expansion and routine passaging of hNPCs. HNPCs should be passaged when the cells reach 70–80% confluence. Healthy cell growth should require passaging every 3–4 days. This protocol describes expansion of hNPCs in 6-well plates. The protocol should be adjusted appropriately for expansion in other tissue culture plate formats.
When the cells reach 70–80% confluence (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C), aspirate the medium and add 1 mL of Accutase.
Incubate the plate with Accutase at 37°C for 5 min.
Wash the well with 1 mL of NEM to remove adherent cells (blast cells with P1000 where necessary).
Transfer cell suspension to a 15 mL conical tube. Take 10 μL of the cell suspension and count cells using a hemocytometer.
Centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing cell pellet.
Resuspend cell pellet in NEM so that the final cell concentration is 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Plate the cells at a density of 2.5 × 104/cm2 onto fresh PLO/Ln coated plates that have been washed twice with PBS prior to use.
Add the appropriate volume of NEM to each well so that the final volume per well is 3mL.
Place the plate in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator. Gently move the plate in several quick, short, back-and-forth, and side-to-side motions to spread cells evenly across the wells.
Each passage increases the passage number by 1.

Cells should continue to display similar flat morphology as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C. Cells should be characterized at passage 6 with >90% of the cells should expressing SOX1, SOX2, and NESTIN (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D). Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Cryopreservation of hNPCs
Timing: 1 day
This step describes the cryopreservation of hNPCs. HNPCs should be passaged between passage 5 and 10 for use in large-scale differentiations. We recommend cryopreserving hNPCs on passage 5 after characterization. Before starting this step, prepare the Freezing Medium.
When the cells reach 70–80% confluence, aspirate the medium and wash once with PBS. Then, add 1 mL of Accutase.
Wash the well with 1 mL of NEM to remove adherent cells (blast cells with P1000 where necessary).
Transfer cell suspension to a 15 mL conical tube. Take 10 μL of the cell suspension and count cells using the hemocytometer.
Centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.
Resuspend the pellet in Freezing Medium so that the final cell concentration is 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Transfer 1 mL of cell suspension to a cryovial and transfer to a Mr. Frosty™ freezing container.
Place the Mr. Frosty™ in a −80°C freezer for 24 h before transferring the cryovial to a −150°C freezer.
Pause point: HNPCs can be stored at −150°C for 1 year.
Thawing of hNPCs
Timing: 3–4 days
This step describes the thawing of cryopreserved hNPCs. We recommend that hNPCs be expanded a minimum of 2 passages after thawing before proceeding with large-scale differentiation.
Quickly thaw a vial of hNPCs (1 × 106 cells/vial) in a bead bath and add cell suspension to 4 mL DMEM in a 15 mL conical.
Centrifuge cells at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.

Resuspend cell pellet in 1 mL NEM.
Plate at an appropriate density (25–50% higher than density at which cells are routinely cultured; Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E) and expand hNPCs on PLO/Ln coated plates as described in steps 41–51.
Coating of microcarriers (MCs) with vitronectin-derived peptide (VDP)
Timing: 2 days
In this protocol, a fully defined peptide substrate—termed vitronectin-derived peptide (VDP)—will be employed as a growth substrate for the large-scale differentiation of hNPCs in a microcarrier (MC)-based suspension culture system (Srinivasan et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib31]; Varun et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib35]). This step describes the coating of MCs with VDP. Although this protocol can be adapted to be used with PLO/Ln coated MCs, VDP provides a more reproducible and cost-effective substrate for the large-scale expansion and differentiation of hNPCs.
Sterilize weighing scale with 70% ethanol and transfer to tissue culture hood. Weigh 200 mg of sterile MCs and transfer to a 15 mL conical using a disposable spatula and weigh paper.
Add 5 mL PBS to 15 mL conical.
Using a P1000, mix the MCs in PBS by pipetting up and down.
Transfer 500 μL (approximately 20 mg) of MC suspension to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Centrifuge the Eppendorf tube at 200 × g for 3 min.
Using a P1000, aspirate 50 μL PBS from the Eppendorf tube and replace with 50 μL VDP stock solution.
Using a P1000, mix the MCs well in VDP solution by pipetting up and down.
Incubate MCs with VDP for 48 h at 37°C.
Immediately before use, centrifuge the Eppendorf tube at 200 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the MC pellet.
Gently add 1 mL PBS to resuspend the MCs. Do not pipette the MCs up and down vigorously.
Centrifuge the Eppendorf tube at 200 × g for 3 min.

Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the MC pellet. Gently add 1 mL NEM.
Centrifuge the Eppendorf tube at 200 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the MC pellet. Gently add 1 mL NEM. This is later added to the cell suspension prepared as described below.
Large-scale neural differentiation of hNPCs on VDP-coated MCs
Timing: ∼30 days
This section describes the expansion of hNPCs on VDP-coated MCs as well as their subsequent differentiation to neurons and astrocytes through the removal of FGF and EGF and addition of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and glial derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF). Prior to starting this step, prepare the Neural Differentiation Medium (NDM).
Dissociate a healthy, confluent hNPC culture as described in steps 41–47. Resuspend the hNPCs at a concentration of 2 × 106 cell/mL in NEM.
In a 15 mL conical, mix 2 × 106 cells in suspension, 130 μL washed VDP-coated MCs, 870 μL warmed NEM, and 2 μL ROCKi. The total volume of 1 well of a 6-well plate should be 2 mL.
Transfer contents of 15 mL conical to a single well of a 6-well cell-repellent plate. If seeding cells in more than one well of a 6-well plate, make sure to mix MCs and cells well and seed one well at a time using a 5mL serological pipette.
Place the plate in static conditions in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 12 h.
Add 2 mL of NEM and 2 μL ROCKi to the well.
Place the plate on an orbital shaker set at 95 rpm in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator.
After 24 h, use a P1000 to remove 3 mL of media and replace with 3 mL of fresh NEM.

Every day, use a P1000 to remove 2 mL of media and replace with 2mL of fresh NEM.
Critical: While changing the media, swirl the aggregates to the middle of each well to ensure no cell aggregates are accidently removed.
Continue changing the media until the cells are confluent, approximately 4–5 days after seeding the MCs. There should be a thin layer of cells surrounding the MC aggregates (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A, left panel). The hNPCs should continue to express high levels of SOX1, SOX2, and NESTIN when grown on the MCs. Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].

(A) Representative images of MC aggregate on day 1 (left panel) and day 30 (right panel) of differentiation.
(B) Representative images of poorly differentiating MC aggregates. Red arrows are pointing to patches of cells detaching from the MCs.
Once confluent, use a P1000 to remove 3 mL of NEM and replace with 3 mL of NDM.

The MC aggregates will continue to grow in size throughout the differentiation (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A, right panel). Troubleshooting 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Dissociation of cells from the MCs
Timing: ∼5 h
This step describes the enzymatic dissociation of differentiated neural cells from the MC-based cultures into single-cell suspension. This protocol is a modification of a previously published protocol for the single-cell dissociation of organoid-based cultures (Sloan et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib30]). Prior to starting this step prepare the Enzyme and Inhibitor (E/I) Stock Solution, the Low Concentration Ovomucoid Solution and the High Concentration Ovomucoid Solution.

Critical: This protocol is written for dissociation of 2 wells of 6-well plate of MC cultures. Dissociation of additional wells should be performed in parallel and not combined into a single 50 mL conical tube.
Label a 50 mL conical tube ‘Low concentration ovomucoid inhibitor solution’. Add 27.8 mL E/I stock solution to the conical. Label another 50 mL conical tube ‘High concentration ovomucoid inhibitor solution’. Add 5 mL solution to the conical.
Place both conicals upright in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator with screw caps loosened to allow for equilibration. Alternatively, adjust the pH of E/I stock solution prior to use with 1N HCl and skip the equilibration step.
Prepare a 30U/mL papain enzyme solution by adding the appropriate volume of papain, 75 μL L-Cysteine stock solution, and 14.4 mL of E/I stock solution to a 50 mL conical.
Note: The volume of papain enzyme solution may vary according to enzyme stock concentration. The final concentration must be at 30 U/mL. The solution will be cloudy when the papain stock is added.
Critical: Do not add the DNase I at this step. It will be added at a later step.
Incubate the papain enzyme solution at 37°C for 20 min until the solution becomes clear.
Filter the papain enzyme solution with a 0.2 μm filter into a new 50 mL conical.
After filter sterilization, add 94 μL DNase I stock solution to the papain enzyme solution.
Using a 25 mL serological pipette, transfer 2 wells of MCs to a 15 mL conical tube. Wash the well with 3 mL NBM to transfer any remaining aggregates left in the well.
Centrifuge the conical at 200 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and add 2 mL of Accutase per well.
Incubate for 5 min at 37°C.

Use a P1000 to gently break up the aggregates by pipetting up down several times.
Add 2 mL of NBM to the 15 mL conical.
Centrifuge the conical at 200 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and add 4 mL papain enzyme solution that was prepared in step 96.
Using a 5 mL serological pipette, transfer the aggregates in papain enzyme solution to 2 wells of a 6-well cell-repellent plate at 2 mL per well.
Place the plate on an orbital shaker set at 95 rpm in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator. Incubate for 70 min.
During the incubation period, finish preparing the low and high concentration ovomucoid inhibitor solutions.
For the low concentration ovomucoid inhibitor solution, thaw the low concentration ovomucoid solution on ice. To the 50 mL conical prepared in step 92, add 2 mL of low concentration ovomucoid solution and 188 μL DNase I.
For the high concentration ovomucoid inhibitor solution, thaw the high concentration ovomucoid solution on ice. To the 50 mL conical prepared in step 92, add 1 mL of high concentration ovomucoid solution and 38 μL DNase I.
After incubation in papain enzyme, transfer cells from the 6-well cell-repellent plate to a 15 mL conical.
Centrifuge the conical at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate supernatant and add 4 mL low concentration ovomucoid inhibitor solution prepared in step 108a.
Use a 5 mL serological pipette to gently pipette the aggregates up and down 15 times.
Critical: Do not introduce bubbles while pipetting as this may lead to cell damage and death.
Allow undissociated aggregates to settle down and transfer cloudy cell suspension to a new 15 mL conical.
Repeat steps 111–113 with a P1000 until aggregates are broken up into single cell suspension. Triturate slightly more vigorously each round.

Put a 40 μm cell strainer over a new 15 mL conical and, using a P1000, slowly pass all the single cell-MC suspension obtained in step 114 through the filter.
Note: Change the cell strainer if it gets clogged with MCs. For higher yields, wash the cell strainer 1 to 2 times with low concentration ovomucoid inhibitor solution to ensure all single cells have passed through.
Centrifuge the single cell suspension at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend in 6 mL low ovomucoid inhibitor solution.
In a new 15 mL conical tube, add 6 mL of high ovomucoid inhibitor solution prepared in step 108b.
Add the resuspended single cell suspension obtained in step 117 to the 15 mL conical with the high ovomucoid inhibitor solution prepared in step 118 dropwise.
Note: This step will allow for the removal of cell debris from the single cell suspension. When added slowly, the low ovomucoid cell suspension will stay on top of the high ovomucoid solution.
Centrifuge the conical at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend in 10 mL of warm NDM supplemented with 5uM ROCKi with a P1000.
Note: Resuspend with 1 mL NDM first to ensure the pellet is thoroughly broken up prior to adding the remaining 9 mL NDM.
Incubate the cell suspension for 1 h in a 15 mL conical tube in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator to allow the cells to recover from the dissociation.
Count the cells using a hemocytometer.
Take 1 × 106 cells and proceed with the cell viability assay as described in step 190 (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A). The remainder of the cells can be purified using magnetic activated cell sorting (MACS) as described in step 125.

Purification of neurons and astrocytes from neural cultures using magnetic activated cell sorting (MACS)
Timing: ∼3 h
In this section, a MACS step employing an established astrocyte-specific cell surface marker, CD44 (Liu et al., 2004[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib19]), is used to purify mixed neural populations into astrocytes and neurons.
Prepare 10 mL of 1× MojoSort™ Buffer by adding 2 mL of 5× MojoSort™ Buffer and 8 mL of sterile distilled water to a 15 mL conical tube.
Centrifuge cell suspension obtained in step 121 at 300 × g for 10 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and add 5 mL 1× MojoSort™ Buffer to the cell pellet without resuspending the pellet.
Centrifuge cells in 1× MojoSort™ Buffer for 300 × g for 10 min.
Critical: The maximum number of cells that can sorted at one time should not exceed 2.5 × 108 cells. To that end, if more than 2.5 × 108 cells are isolated then the cells should be separated evenly into multiple 15 mL conical tubes.
Resuspend cell pellet with 1× MojoSort™ Buffer so that the final cell concentration is 1 × 108 cell/mL and add the cell suspension to a polypropylene tube.
Add 1 μL per 1 × 106 cells of Biotin-CD44 to the tube.
Gently flick the tube to mix the antibody and cell suspension.
Incubate conical on ice for 15 min.
Vortex Streptavidin nanobeads 5 times.
Add 1 μL Streptavidin nanobeads per 1 × 106 cells to the tube.

Gently flick the tube to mix the nanobeads and cell suspension.
Incubate on ice for 15 min.
Critical: At this step, no more than 2.5 mL of 1× buffer, 250 μL Biotin-CD44 antibody, and 250 μL of Streptavidin Nanobeads should have been added. The magnet can sort a maximum of 3 mL of solution (∼2.5 × 108 cells) at once. As such, if more than 2.5 × 108 cells are being purified then MACS sorting of parallel cell preparations staggered by 5 min should be performed.
Place the tube in the MojoSort™ magnet so that the solution is completely covered by the magnet. Loosely place a cap on top of the tube. It should not be sealed.
Leave the magnet in place for 5 min.
With the magnet still in place, decant the CD44- fraction into a new polypropylene tube labeled ‘CD44- cells’ in one motion.
Repeat steps 137–139 for higher purity of CD44- cells.
Note: The CD44+ cells from step 138 will be used in step 141. Do not combine the CD44+ cells left after a second round of MACS separation with the cells from step 138.
After the second round of MACS separation, add cells to a 15 mL conical labeled ‘CD44-cells’ and centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min. Herein, these cells will be referred to as neurons.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 10 mL warm NDM.
Count the cells with a hemocytometer. Troubleshooting 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Proceed to step 175 for replating of neurons or step 181 for cryopreservation of neurons.
Using the CD44+ fraction from step 138, resuspend the cells in 12 mL of warmed Astrocyte Medium supplemented with 5 μM ROCKi and transfer the cells to a 15 mL conical labeled ‘CD44+ cells’. Herein, these cells will be referred to as astrocytes.

Count the cells using a hemocytometer. Troubleshooting 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Proceed to step 143 for replating and culturing of the astrocytes.
Astrocyte culture
Timing: ∼2 weeks
In this section, we described the plating and expansion of MACS purified astrocytes. After culture, these astrocytes can be characterized for their expression of high levels of mature astrocytic markers (step 209) as well as properties characteristic of functionally mature astrocytes including production of Apolipoprotein E (ApoE; step 228) and appearance of robust calcium transients (step 235). This protocol describes the culture of astrocytes in 6-well plates. The protocol should be adjusted appropriately for expansion in other tissue culture plate formats.
Transfer 2.5 × 105 cells from the cell suspension obtained in step 142 to each well of a Cultrex® BME-coated 6-well plate.
Note: Because the Streptavidin Nanobeads might still be attached to the astrocytes, the cell counts obtained via the hemocytometer might be inaccurate. To that end, the user can elect to split the astrocyte cell suspension obtained in step 143 into empirically determined ratios onto Cultrex® BME-coated plates. We have found that evenly splitting the astrocyte cell suspension obtained in step 143 into 4 wells of a Cultrex® BME-coated plate will allow for robust attachment and growth.
Add appropriate amount of warmed Astrocyte Medium supplemented with 5 μM ROCKi so that the total volume per well is 3 mL.
Place the plate in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator. Gently move the plate in several quick, short, back-and-forth, and side-to-side motions to spread cells evenly across the wells.
After 24 h replace the medium with 3 mL of fresh Astrocyte Medium. Troubleshooting 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Change the medium each day (∼5 days) until the wells are 90% confluent.
When the cultures are 90% confluent aspirate the medium and add 1 mL of Accutase to each well.

Incubate in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 5 min.
Add 2mL of Astrocyte medium to each well with Accutase.
Mechanically dissociate cells from the bottom of the well with a P1000 pipette.
Count the cells using a hemocytometer.
Transfer the cells to a 15 mL conical and centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend in 5 mL of warmed Astrocyte Medium.
Transfer 2.5 × 105 cells from the cell suspension to each well of a Cultrex® BME-coated 6-well plate.
Note: Cell plating density may vary with each cell line. To find the optimal seeding density, plate the cells at a gradient of cell density (e.g. 1 × 105, 2 × 105, 3 × 105) and use the density at which the cells become 90% confluent 3–4 days after passaging.
Add appropriate amount of warmed Astrocyte Medium supplemented with 5 μM ROCKi so that the total volume per well is 3 mL.
Place the plate in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator. Gently move the plate in several quick, short, back-and-forth, and side-to-side motions to spread cells evenly across the wells.
Change the medium each day with 3 mL of warmed Astrocyte Medium.
When 90% confluent, passage the cells as describe in steps 148–156.
Astrocytes can be cryopreserved as described in step 161 or characterized as described in steps 209, 228, and 235.
Note: The astrocyte pellets during each passage will appear brown or darker in color because some of the streptavidin nanobeads will still be attached. Around passage 4, the nanobeads should be mostly removed. Because the attachment of the nanobeads to the cell surface of the astrocytes can interfere with downstream assays, we recommend proceeding with any characterization or experimental assays after passage 4 but prior to passage 10.
Cryopreservation of astrocytes

Timing: 1 day
This step describes the cryopreservation of astrocytes. We recommend cryopreserving astrocytes on passage 4 for use in subsequent experiments or assays.
When the cells reach 90% confluence, aspirate the medium and add 1 mL of Accutase.
Wash the well with 1 mL of DMEM to remove adherent cells (blast cells with P1000 where necessary).
Transfer cell suspension to a 15 mL conical tube. Take 10 μL of the cell suspension and count cells using a hemocytometer.
Centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.
Resuspend the pellet in Freezing Medium so that the final cell concentration is 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Transfer 1 mL of cell suspension to a cryovial and transfer to a Mr. Frosty™ freezing container.
Place the Mr. Frosty™ in a −80°C freezer for 24 h before transferring the cryovial to a −150°C freezer.
Thawing of astrocytes
Timing: 3–4 days
This step describes the thawing of cryopreserved astrocytes. We recommend that astrocytes be cultured for a minimum of 3 days before proceeding with characterization or other experimental assays.
Quickly thaw a vial of astrocytes (1 × 106 cells/vial) in a bead bath and add cell suspension to 4 mL DMEM in a 15 mL conical.
Centrifuge cells at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing cell pellet.
Resuspend cell pellet in 1 mL Astrocyte Medium.
Plate and expand astrocytes on Cultrex® BME-coated plates as described in steps 144–159. Troubleshooting 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Characterize astrocytes as described in steps 209, 228, 235.
Note: Allow the astrocytes to recover for a minimum of 3 days before proceeding the characterization assays.
Neuron culture
Timing: ∼7–10 days

In this section, we described the plating of MACS purified neurons. After culture, these neurons can be characterized for their expression of high levels of mature post-mitotic neuronal markers (step 209) as well as characteristics of functionally mature neurons such as the appearance of spontaneous calcium transients (step 235). This protocol describes the culture of neurons in 24-well plates. The protocol should be adjusted appropriately for expansion in other tissue culture plate formats.
Transfer 1 × 106 cells from the cell suspension obtained in step 140 to each well of a Cultrex® BME-coated 24-well plate.
Note: Optimal plating density will be cell-line dependent but typically range 1–2 × 106 cells/well.
Add appropriate amount of warmed NDM supplemented with 5 μM ROCKi so that the total volume per well is 1 mL.
Place the plate in the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator. Gently move the plate in several quick, short, back-and-forth, and side-to-side motions to spread cells evenly across the wells.
After 24 h, use a P1000 to remove the medium and replace with 1 mL of fresh NDM. Troubleshooting 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Note: Neurons, especially 24–48 h post-plating, are very fragile and may be susceptible to peeling off the plate. While removing and adding the medium, it is important to use caution.
Using a P1000, change half the medium every other day until axonal projections appear (7–10 days; Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A).
Proceed with experimental assays or characterization as described in steps 209 and 235.
Cryopreservation of neurons
Timing: 1 h
This step describes the cryopreservation of neurons without loss of viability or functionality.
Centrifuge the MACS-purified neurons obtained in step 140 at 300 × g for 10 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend in CryoStor so that the final concentration is 20 × 106 cells/mL.

Transfer 1 mL of cell suspension to a cryovial and transfer to a Mr. Frosty™ freezing container.
Place the Mr. Frosty™ in a −80°C freezer for 24 h before transferring the cryovial to a −150°C freezer.
Pause point: Neurons can be stored at −150°C for 2 years at least.
Thawing of neurons
Timing: 7–10 days
This step describes the thawing of cryopreserved neurons. We recommend that neurons be cultured for a minimum of 7–10 days before proceeding with characterization or other experimental assays.
Quickly thaw a vial of neurons in a bead bath. Transfer cell suspension to a 50mL conical and add 5 mL NDM dropwise. Swirl gently to mix and transfer to a 15 mL conical.
Centrifuge cells at 300 × g for 5 min at RT.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.
Resuspend cell pellet in 1 mL NDM supplemented with 5 μM ROCKi.
Plate and culture neurons on Cultrex® BME-coated plates as described in steps 175–178. Troubleshooting 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Characterize neurons as described in steps 209 and 235.
Note: Allow the neurons to recover for a minimum of 7 days after thawing prior to assaying.
Assessment of viability of neuronal and astrocytic cell populations by flow cytometry
Timing: ∼2 h
This section describes the protocol for assessing the viability of dissociated, MACS-purified cell populations with Calcein-AM and Propidium Iodide (PI). This assessment can also be performed upon thawing of cryopreserved cell populations.
Collect 1 × 106 cells in suspension and place in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Centrifuge cells at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.
Resuspend cell pellet in 500 μL of 50 nM Calcein AM diluted in PBS.
Incubate cells on ice, protected from light, for 30 min.

Wash the cells with 1 mL of PBS twice by centrifugation at 200 × g for 5 min at RT after each wash.
Resuspend the cells in 500 μL PBS.
Add 1μL of 1.5 mM stock PI. Mix by pipetting gently up and down with a P1000.
Note: For each sample, prepare single Calcein-AM and PI-stained along with unstained samples.
Analyze the cells with a flow cytometer and use the single- and un-stained samples to set gates and color compensation using FlowJo analysis software (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). Troubleshooting 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Characterization of neurons and astrocytes by flow cytometry
Timing: ∼2 h
This step describes the characterization of MACS-purified populations by flow cytometry for expression of CD44. This protocol can be adapted to analyze cell populations for expression of other cell surface markers.
Collect 1 × 106 cells in suspension and place in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Centrifuge cells at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.
Resuspend cell pellet in 1 mL PBS.
Add 40 ul of PE mouse anti-human CD44 to the tube.
Note: For each sample, prepare a separate tube with the appropriate negative isotype control.
Incubate, protected from light, at 4°C for 1 h.
Wash the cells with 1 mL of PBS twice by centrifugation at 200 × g for 5 min at RT after each wash.
Resuspend the cells in 200 μL PBS.
Analyze the cells with a flow cytometer and use the negative isotype controls to set gates using FlowJo analysis software (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A and 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C). Troubleshooting 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].

Characterization of neurons and astrocytes by immunofluorescence
Timing: 2 days
This section describes characterization of MACS-purified cell populations for neuronal (MAP2, NEUN, TUJ1), synaptic (vGlut1, PSD95), cortical (FOXG1, TBR1, CTIP2, SATB2) and astrocytic (S100β) markers. This protocol can be adapted to analyze cell populations for other markers. We recommend that cells be plated in 24-well plates for immunofluorescent assays. For assessing synaptic marker expression, cells can be plated on #1.5 coverslips to allow for confocal imaging.
Aspirate the medium from adherent cultures. For neurons, use a P1000 to aspirate.
Wash wells once with 500 μL PBS.
Aspirate PBS and add 300 μL of fixation buffer.
Incubate at RT for 15 min, protected from light.
Aspirate fixation buffer and wash wells twice with 500 μL PBS.
Aspirate PBS and add 300 μL of permeabilization buffer (Phosflow Perm Buffer III).
Incubate at 4°C for 30 min.
Aspirate permeabilization buffer and wash wells twice with 500 μL PBS.
Aspirate PBS and add 300 μL of primary antibody diluted in PBS at the concentration indicated in the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Incubate primary antibody 12–24 h at 4°C, protected from light.
Aspirate primary antibody and wash wells twice with 500 μL PBS.
Aspirate PBS and add 300 μL of the corresponding secondary antibody diluted in PBS at the concentration indicated in the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Incubate secondary antibody for 1 h at RT, protected from light.
Aspirate secondary antibody and wash wells twice with 500 μL PBS.
Aspirate PBS and add Hoechst diluted 1:5000 in PBS.
Incubate for 10 min at RT, protected from light.
Aspirate Hoechst and wash wells twice with 500 μL PBS.
Leave 500 μL PBS in each well.

Pause point: Stained plates may be stored at 4°C, protected from light, for 1 week prior to imaging.
Image wells with a fluorescent microscope. (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, 4C, 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A, 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B, 6D–6F, 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A, and 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]C).

Characterization of astrocytes for secretion of Apolipoprotein E (APOE)
Timing: ∼1 week
This section describes the characterization of MACS-purified astrocytes for their ability to secrete robust amounts of APOE. APOE is a lipoprotein transporter that plays critical roles related to cholesterol transport, neuronal growth, synaptic plasticity, and cell membrane repair (Lane-Donovan and Herz, 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib17]; Suri et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib32]). In the central nervous system, APOE is primarily generated and secreted by functionally mature astrocytes. This protocol describes the characterization of astrocytes plated in adherent cultures in 24-well plates. The protocol should be adjusted appropriately for expansion in other tissue culture plate formats. Prior to starting this step prepare the TBS and Cell Lysis Buffer.
Allow plated astrocytes to reach 60–70% confluence.
Aspirate the medium and replace 600 μL of fresh Astrocyte Medium.
Allow the cells to grow in 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 6 days.

On day 6, collect the conditioned medium in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Centrifuge the condition medium at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Transfer the supernatant to a fresh 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Pause point: The supernatant can be stored at -80°C for 1 month.
Using the manufacturer’s protocol, quantify the APOE protein in the conditioned medium using the APOE ELISA.
Add 300 μL cell lysis buffer to each well.
Use a P1000 to triturate the lysis buffer and mechanically lyse the cells.
Transfer cell lysate to 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube and centrifuge at 12000 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a fresh 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Pause point: The supernatant can be stored at -80°C for 1 month.
Using the manufacturer’s protocol, quantify the total protein concentration in the cell lysate using the Bradford Assay Kit.
For each well, normalize the APOE protein concentration to the total protein concentration (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Characterization of calcium transients in MACS-purified astrocytes and neurons
Timing: 1 week
The section describes the use of fluorescent imaging for the assessment of calcium transients in MACS-purified astrocytes and neurons. A canonical property of both functionally mature astrocytes and neurons is the presence of spontaneous calcium transients (Ikegaya et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13]; Shigetomi et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib29]). More specifically, astrocytes typically display slow, broad calcium transients while neurons exhibit rapid, frequent peaks of calcium transients. Prior to starting this step, prepare the BrainPhys Neuronal Medium, Neuron Calcium Imaging Solution, and Astrocyte Calcium Imaging Solution.
Culture neurons in NDM on Cultrex® BME-coated 24-well MatTek glass bottom plates for 7 days.
On day 7, aspirate the NDM using a P1000 and replace with 1 mL of BrainPhys Neuronal medium.
Leave the neurons in BrainPhys media for 2 days.

On day 9, aspirate the BrainPhys-SM1 medium and add 1 mL of Neuron Calcium Imaging Solution to the well.
Incubate for 30 min at 37°C.
Aspirate the Neuron Calcium Imaging Solution and wash once with 1 mL of warm Tyrode’s Solution. Leave in Tyrode’s solution.
Incubate at RT for 15 min, protected from light.
Use a fluorescent microscope to image calcium transients at a frame rate of 1 per second and 20× magnification. Image for a minimum of 5 min at 37°C.
Culture astrocytes in Astrocyte Medium on Cultrex® BME-coated 24-well MatTek glass bottom plates for 4 days.
Note: Astrocytes should be 80–90% confluent by day 4.
On day 4, aspirate the Astrocyte Medium and wash the wells with 1 mL of PBS.
Aspirate the PBS and add 1 mL of Astrocyte Calcium Imaging Solution to the well.
Incubate for 15 min at 37°C.
Aspirate the Astrocyte Calcium Imaging Solution and wash once with 1 mL of warm Tyrode’s Solution. Leave in Tyrode’s solution.
Incubate at RT for 10 min, protected from light.
Use a fluorescent microscope to image calcium transients at a frame rate of 1 per second and 20× magnification. Image for a minimum of 5 min at 37°C.
Calcium imaging analysis.
Add the AQUA plugin to Fiji as described: https://github.com/yu-lab-vt/AQua[href=https://github.com/yu-lab-vt/AQua].
Convert the .nd2 calcium imaging video to a 1024 pixel video from a 2048 pixel video. Save as .tiff file using Fiji.
Create a New Folder to save the results from analysis of each video.
Start Fiji. Open AQUA plugin.
Select New Project.
Select the video to be analyzed and the folder to save the results in. Click OK.
Run the program with the parameters listed in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].

Export and save the results (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C, 5D, 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B, and 7C).

Note: For each video, the exported results will contain two files ‘Aqua_Curve_Output.csv’ and ‘Aqua_Output_Excel.csv’. Visual images of the cells (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C and 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B) before, during, and after a calcium spike can be generated in Fiji with their respective ΔF/F graphs generated from the ‘Aqua_Curve_Output.csv’. For quantification (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]D and 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]C), the average peak height and the maximum peak height can be extracted from the data contained in the ‘Aqua_Output_excel.csv’ file. The number of peaks fired (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]D and 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]C) can be determined by generating a ‘Line Sparkline’ for each event from the ‘Aqua_Curve_Output.csv’ file.
